AXolotl Proof \?? This is a really long sentence to illustrate the scroll This is a really long sentence to illustrate the scroll This is a really long sentence in order to illustrate the scrolling This is a really long sentence used for illustrating the scroll Open navigation drawer Close navigation drawer Instance Term Variable x y z Problem and Rules Resulting Problem State Observation Mode Problems Propositional Logic Prop 01 Modal Logic Matching Substitution Term State Function Symbols Terms To Match Current Substitution } { Rule List Substitution Term Function Symbols Apply Hello blank fragment open close ⚫ Constructed Term Variable List Substitution List Term Matching Non-Classical Change in Problem State Axolotl Character Image AXolotl Character Head Problem Text Size View Proof Proof button menu Symbol Problem button menu symbol Classical Logic Non-Classical Logic Hilbert Style Sequent Style AXolotl for LandLayout equal sign HELP Acknowledgements On load screen Natural Deduction http://fmv.jku.at/logtechedu/ The development of this application was partially funded by the Linz Institute of Technology (LIT) SEED Project LOGTECHEDU hosted by the Institute for Formal Methods and Verification (FMV) and the Research Institute of Symbolic Computation (RISC) of the Johannes Kepler University (JKU).
Goal
To provide students of computer science and possibly other subjects with a game-like self-study environment which they can use to familiarize themselves with the basic concepts of formal reasoning, formal logic, and term re-writing systems.
Members
David M. Cerna, is a member of the LOGTECHEDU project. He provided the conceptual design and software architecture. 
 Rafael Kiesl, is a PhD student of the computational logic program at the Technical University of Vienna, was the main software developer. 
 Alexandra Dzhyganska, provided the look and feel of the application and various design elements. Welcome to AXolotl a self-study tool for formal reasoning and Logic. The above image displays the start screen when the App is first opened. In order to start using AXolotl you can click on the "hamburger" menu ☰ or the "kebap" menu ⋮ to choose a problem or open a proble. 

 To move onto the section of this tutorial swipe right. If you feel the need to go back to an earlier section swipe left. If you choose to click on ⋮ the above image illustrates what you will see on the screen. If you have not started a problem you may click on Load Problem to open an AXolotl compatible file. If you have finished your problem you have an option to save the proof as a jpeg image by clicking on Save Proof Picture or as a latex file by clicking on Save Latex Proof to Clipboard. The other options are probably familiar to you already, namely, Help and About. 

 To move onto the section of this tutorial swipe right. If you feel the need to go back to an earlier section swipe left. If you choose to click on ☰ the above image illustrates what you will see on the screen. If you have not started a problem, clicking on Problem will return you to the initial screen. Normally, clicking on Problem returns you to the problem screen which we will see shortly. If you instead click on View Proof you will instead be brought to the proof view which is currently empty (unless you have started a problem). The next two options in the hamburger menu concern the process of solving a chosen problem. 

 When the AXolotl loads observation mode is activated. This means that AXolotl will provide you with all the details of your progress when solving a problem. Once you get use to the interface, problem solving, and understand how a given formal system works you may choose to deactivate observation mode. In this case AXolotl will only inform you when it requires action from you. Concerning Text size, when the AXolotl loads the text size is set to 30sp. You can adjust the text size to any size between 10sp and 50sp. The remaining options in the hamburger menu are problem list. In particular we will click on Classical logic.

 To move onto the section of this tutorial swipe right. If you feel the need to go back to an earlier section swipe left.
